Award.AwardTitle: Quantum Optics with Single Optical Cycles
Award.AbstractNarration: In recent years technologies have been developed to generate pulses shorter than five femtoseconds in duration, thus consisting of less than two optical cycles in full-width half-maximum of the pulse. Such pulses are generally referred to as attosecond pulses, and the ability to produce them has created a new field of attosecond science. The present experimental research program will investigate a new approach for attosecond science and clarify some important questions underlying attosecond physics. Tailored single optical cycles will be used for analyzing interference phenomena in photoelectron spectra. The dependence of the interference patterns on the absolute phase of the few-cycle pulses will make it possible to infer the dynamics of electronic transitions. The technique will be developed using alkali atoms, but is expected to be applicable to molecules, too. There the dynamics of electronic transitions has a major impact on molecular reactions. The broader impact of the program involves the training of students as well as applications to other fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we studied interaction of intense and ultrashort laser pulses with atomic, molecular and condensed matter systems, extending the frontiers of knowledge on the behavior of these systems, when they are subjected to strong electromagnetic fields lasting only few cycles. At the heart of many of such interactions lies photoionization, releasing electrons from the parent atoms or molecules. In particular, above threshold ionization, providing electrons with some additional energy from the many interacting photons (Fig. 1), and fragmentation of molecules by the laser field (Fig. 2) were investigated.  To obtain accurate information on the parameters describing such interactions, the phase of the laser field and its distribution in the interaction region (Fig. 3) were taken into account. In particular, precision single-shot measurements of the carrier-envelope phase of few-cycle laser pulses were performed, and methods for intensity-resolved measurements of nonlinear interactions of intense laser pulses with atomic and molecular systems were developed. The large spectral bandwidth of the few cycle laser pulses was used for detection of the coupling of surface plasmon modes in metal nanostructures (Fig.4).  The strongly nonlinear character of the intensity dependences in the ion yields and the output of high harmonics (Fig. 5), generated in a noble gas jet and extending to the extreme ultraviolet spectral region were observed. In the case of the presence of intermediate energy states in the systems, also the manifestation of resonances of the photon manifold with these energy levels was observed. Of particular importance are possibilities to optimize the desired interactions, and in this respect such avenues as coherent control with an evolutionary algorithm and tailoring the wave front with a spatial light modulator were explored. The project attracted many graduate and undergraduate students and provided them with training and experience in ultrafast and nonlinear laser optics, optoelectronics, and computer control of experiments and processing of experimental data. The research boosted interdepartmental collaborations between groups within Texas A&M University and also stimulated exchanges with national and international groups, working at the frontiers of the ultrafast laser science.
